data.formatted_address: 475 Zhong Shan Dong Yi Lu, Waitan, Huang Pu Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200120
data.name: The Bund Historical Museum

reviews.text: You can get one of the best views to Lujiazui（ 陆家嘴), including the Oriental Pearl TV tower. It was not so crowded compared to other spots on the Bund. I would totally recommend to visit for taking pictures in the early evening.
The Bund History Museum is a small museum with having collection of pictures and stories of the Bund development. It's located right under the People's Heroes Memorial Tower...
very awesome when night come...playing lighting unforgottable

I went through this museum in 2002 and marveled at the historical dioramas that were on display there.  Unfortunately there were signs that no photographs could be taken inside the museum proper so I don't have good documentation.
It was clear that the dioramas had been around for decades and I gather the the museum was an "Indoctrination museum" aimed at Chinese students and citizens, but with signs that had recently been translated into English (among other international languages).
What I found amazing was the dichotomy between the nationalist communist propagandistic words used in the signage and the local pride evident in Shanghai and its history as a cosmopolitan and international center of commerce and culture.
I gather that Shanghai has long been viewed with suspicion by much of the rest of China, given that it was opened by the Western Powers and Japan.   It's morals and ethics were suspect -- perhaps like some of us view Las Vegas.
The signs would read like, "Here in Shanghai in 1883, the first modern waterworks in all of Asia was built by the capitalist running dog imperialist forces from England." and
"Here we see a model of the first electrical lighting system complete with streetlights built by the European Imperialist Capitalist Running Dogs in 1884."
There were revealing photos of a bank building with a sign in English carved into the stone edifice reading,"The Japanese Bank of Tai-Wan" with a detailed history of the imperialist Japanese and the modern banking system they introduced and how the bank personal were overworked and lead to the first strike by workers in China.
It was all very thought provoking.  I suspect that they displays have been revised substantially since the Olympics, but I would love to see photos of those dioramas and signs posted on the internet. History should be preserved even when it doesn't serve propaganda agendas.
Nice places

data.formatted_address: 6FGW+4QG, Bao Dai Long, 四牌楼 Huang Pu Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200010
data.name: Shanghai Old Street

reviews.text: Not a shopping street as shown in review but just a street with worn out traditional building. Not worthwhile to visit at that exact spot as I could only find 2 buildings there worth taking a shot. The main shopping area with lots of food and beautiful traditional building are further away at Yuyuan Old Street (豫园老街).

Lovely area to stroll round. The location is wrong but this road leads you to the right place. Just turn right into the nice area at the end. You can’t miss it. The road where the pin is must have been amazing before all the shops shut down though…
Beautifully preserved architecture that is housing generic tourist stores. The architecture is worth seeing, the stores...not so much
A very beautiful street. Suitable for taking photos and buying souvenirs.

Shanghai Old Street, historically called Miaoqian Dajie, is an old business street that has a combination of tourist attractions, shops, entertainment and cultural exhibits. It owes its special social attractions and rich commercial background to the fact that the earliest bank, gold shop, jeweler's store, wine shop and tea house of the city were all to be found here.

The architecture and the layout of shops in Shanghai Old Street show its development that began during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) until the period when European influence made an impact on the city. The western part of this old street begins at South Henan Road and continues to Guanyi Street. The buildings here reflect the style of the Ming and Qing (1644-1911) dynasties and the architecture is elegant in its classic simplicity. Red poles, pink walls and black roofs with upswept eaves are in harmony with the buildings in Yu Garden. The eastern end of Shanghai Old Street, with a length of 500 meters (about 1,640 feet) ends at Renmin Road and after reconstruction and decoration retains the residential characteristics of later Qing Dynasty. The swing doors reach to the ground, the lattice windows and the graceful roofs with upswept eaves are fascinating as they are precisely how foreigners imagine China to be. Although there are several European buildings, they don't contradict the styles of old Shanghai. On the contrary, they are a vital part of the diverse culture here.
There are about 225 stores on  Shanghai Old Street, each designed carefully according to its function. Shops purveying handicraft articles, paintings, calligraphies and jewelry are well-appointed and give you plenty of variety from which to choose what you want. On the eastern part, old shops such as the Tong Han Chun Pharmacy, Lao Tong Sheng Food Store, Wu Liang Cai Glass Shop, De Shun restaurant, take you back to the Shanghai of 100 years ago. In the Chun Feng De Yi Lou teahouse, you can enjoy Yuanbao Tea served with two olives in it. On weekends, the Pingtan (Suzhou Ballads) are performed here too. In the Old Tea House, the owner has on display a collection of fifty cheongsams, traditionally styled ladies dresses, dating from the 1930s. By contrast at the western end of the street is where items of folk culture may be bought. The antique shops, embroidery houses and wonderful fabric shops symbolize the commercial prosperity of the area.

data.formatted_address: 374 Huang Pi Nan Lu, Huang Pu Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200002
data.name: Site of the First National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party

reviews.text: An interesting place to visit if you like politics & history, gives an insight (albeit heavily skewed) to the Chinese revolution. One minor mention of the Cultural Revolution, so you may wish to have done some other reading before taking this museum at its word.
Worth a visit esp for history buffs. Have an open mind to appreciate a country’s history be it you are from the west or Taiwan. Don’t bring political or values to evaluate history.

Birthplace of the CCP. It looks small but there is a massive exhibition hall underground. Everything is very modern and there are english translations everywhere.
It‘s very interesting to see the history of the CCP with images and original artifacts.
Free entrance and there was no queue today (Sunday).
Everything is new. Not worth the time, go visit the Korean exile government nearby.

Interesting museum on the start of the system with nice old photos. The temporary exhibition on pioneer movement is in Chinese only, unfortunately. Nice souvenir shop inside. Very good places for photos (allowed!). Clear toilets, well organized place. Free entrance, however, fingerprint will taken.

data.formatted_address: China, Shang Hai Shi, 卢湾区香山路7号 邮政编码: 200041
data.name: Former Residence of Sun Yat-Sen

reviews.text:
This is the former residence of Dr Sun Yatsen, the revoluntionary leader against the Qing dynasty and first President/Premier of modern China. It is a peaceful garden house covers an area of about 1000sqm. The building is a two-storey European style built at the beginning of 20th century. Oriented south and north, the outer wall of the house was decorated with gray cobbles, and the roof covered with carmine heart-shaped tiles. The square lawn in the front is surrounded by many beautiful flowers.

The residence was bought over by four Canadian-Chinese and presented to Dr Sun in 1918.

On the day of our visit, it was drizzling there but we still enjoy our visit, it's so peaceful and tranquil and yet get up and closed with the displays and exhibits where history comes alive!
A historical place and I am glad to have my opportunity stepping into the home of my greatly admired figure.

Amazing history and artifacts of one of the most influential figures in the 20th century China. Great museum to visit and learn about the struggle and triumph of Dr. Sun Yat-Sen’s life and commitment, as well as his personal life and love affair. After the visit you will definitely grow a greater sense of appreciation and gratitude to this great man and his idealism.

Closed for renovations until further notice(as of June 2023). Regularly closed on Mondays.

Nice area. Worth checking if reopened when in nearby Fuxing Park.

pretty conspicuous considering he's the founding father of modern china. the place is very hidden as the street is a small one with lots of trees. moreover the signages were not too clear either. upkeep of the building may not warrant the importance of this historical place. sadly.

data.formatted_address: Zhong Shan Dong Yi Lu, Waitan, Huang Pu Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200002
data.name: The Bund

reviews.text: Absolutely beautiful waterfront, you can’t miss out on this when visiting Shanghai. Walkable from Nanxing pedestrian street if you just walk down it. It’s just an enjoyable and relaxing area where you can chill and also sightsee. Definitely recommend taking a boat ride along the river. The view and lights are amazing at night.

Beautiful at night with all the lights of the city. Awesome for photography. Note that all lights go off at 1030pm (or was it 11pm? 🤔). Super crowded. 1km walk from Nanjing Rd East station. Worth a visit.

The river side walkway is very good for a long walk. There are multiple ways to reach. The best option should be to take a metro and get down at Nanjing Road East station and walk for 700m. The views from the bank of the river will be good. Will be super in late evening or night. There is a cruise ship to reach the other side of the river where you can see the Oriental pearl tower.

The river side walkway is very good for a long walk. There are multiple ways to reach. The best option should be to take a metro and get down at Nanjing Road East station and walk for 700m. The views from the bank of the river will be good. Will be super in late evening or night. There is a cruise ship to reach the other side of the river where you can see the Oriental Pearl Tower.  Very good vibes,  night view n day View are good if ur on weekend there is too much crowded if u visit Shanghai China must go

Absolutely beautiful place. Especially at night it is so pretty with all the lights. The view is spectacular. And there is such a diversity in architecture one cannot fathom it until you visit. At one side there are massive skyscrapers, at the others some gorgeous older buildings, and then a few blocks away there is a huge garden full of ancient chinese architecture. Then in another direction there is the longest shopping street in the world.
200/10 can only recommend visiting here.

data.formatted_address: 325 Nan Jing Xi Lu, People's Square, Huang Pu Qu, China, 200003
data.name: Shanghai Historical Museum

reviews.text:
Shanghai History Museum is a nice stop for history enthusiasts and casual visitors alike.

One of the best things about this museum is that admission is free, making it an accessible and budget-friendly attraction for all.

For a dose of culture and history during your Shanghai visit, include the Shanghai History Museum on your itinerary.

Located on the northwest corner of People's Square, the Shanghai History Museum is dedicated to preserving the city's history. The collection focuses on the approximately one hundred years from the treaty opening of the port in 1843 to the communist take-over in 1949. Today, the Shanghai History Museum occupies the main building of the former Shanghai Race Club. The newly renovated and opened space retains much of the original building's architecture and interior design. If you have ever wondered what Old Shanghai was like, you can find the answer at the Shanghai History Museum. As an important cultural attraction, the it is well worth a visit.

Museum locates in the hart of Shanghai in 2 buildings nearby People’s Square. It tells a story about Shanghai’s history and culture from ancient time till nowadays. A lot of attention is paid for the beginning of XX century. The 2nd building is used for museum shop and temporal expositions. Entrance is free.

A cool looking building with a beautiful roof top garden. Compared to Shanghai Museum, it is smaller but with more exhibitions specific to modern Shanghai. I learned all sorts of things like how Shanghai evolved into a financial centre, how the foreign concessions operated after the opium wars and its frontier position as to Sino-Japanese war.
The gift shop is a bit...eh. It sells all sorts of stuff not much to do with its museum itself.
It is completely free and has very interesting information, highly recommended

data.formatted_address: 1843 Huai Hai Zhong Lu, Xu Hui Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200010
data.name: 上海宋庆龄故居

reviews.text: One of the places that I have visited several times in my life is the former residence of Soong Ching Ling, the honorary president of China and a prominent figure in modern Chinese history. I first went there when I was a young student, as part of a summer camp program that introduced us to the cultural and historical heritage of Shanghai. I was deeply impressed by the elegant and spacious house, the beautiful garden, and the rich collection of memorabilia that showcased Soong Ching Ling's remarkable achievements and contributions. I learned a lot about her life, her ideals, and her role in the Chinese revolution and the founding of the People's Republic of China. I also admired her dedication to the welfare of children, women, and minorities, as well as her efforts to promote peace and friendship among nations. I felt inspired by her spirit and vision, and I wanted to follow her example of serving the people and the country.
Lovely park near the centre of Shanghai  and close to some beautiful historical areas. There is a beautiful rose garden in the park as well. If you're walking by,  it's definitely worth exploring!
Whilst I'm not familiar with Ms. SongQingLing, I still found it very interesting. Beautiful old house and grounds.

Very informative tour through Song Qing Ling's prior residence. They've done a good job of preserving everything, from the vintage cars in the garage to the interiors of the bullding to the furnishings and the outside garden. Not crowded at all, so we were able to spend as much time as we wanted to see the exhibits which was nice.
Some of the best Xiao Long Bao I've ever tasted !!

data.formatted_address: China, Shang Hai Shi, Huang Pu Qu, 四牌楼 Yu Yuan Xin Lu, 豫园 邮政编码: 200120
data.name: Yuyuan Old Street

reviews.text: One of the highlights on our visit to Shanghai. I enjoyed this more than the cruise on the Bund. So much to see and food to taste.  The intricate patterns on the buildings make this shopping street reminiscent of Old China in a modern setting.  A bit crowded though- A lot of tourist like me also 😊. Try to visit on a weekday to avoid the crowd. And walk through the garden next to it.

Beautiful place to visit. There are plenty of foods and shops around the area. Must come hungry to try out a lot of foods. Also can buy a lot of foods for souvenirs. A must visit place for tourist in Shanghai.

I would come again when visit Shanghai.

Cart shops can be bargain for the price.

I was there in April and the weather was very cooling! Yuyuan old street is a very famous place for walking street, temple and local snacks and food. You must try this giant dumplings 🥟 and also the Moutai liquor ice cream 🍦 was very yummy! Oh and next to the dumplings shop got this salted egg yolks daifuku which I really like it too 🥹
If you come to Shanghai, you must visit here.

Exploring Yu Yuan Old Street is like taking a journey through Shanghai’s past. The narrow lanes lined with traditional shops and eateries exude old-world charm, making it the perfect place to immerse yourself in the city’s rich history and culture. From souvenir shopping to sampling local delicacies, there’s something for everyone to enjoy on this bustling street. Don’t forget to try the famous xiaolongbao (soup dumplings)!

Definitely a beautiful place to go... It's one of the other sides of Shanghai, as opposed to the tall skyscrapers and the fancy modern buildings and shopping malls.

There are plenty of restaurants and small eateries offering authentic local cuisine and other shops selling souvenirs and etc. Better allocate enough time here.

data.formatted_address: 259 Da Jing Lu, Huang Pu Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200010
data.name: Shanghai Old Town History Exhibition

reviews.text: Must visit in Shanghai, old and historical city. Different and amazing to experience old Shanghai

By far the best place to visit in Shanghai. It reminded me of the old kunfu Chinese movies. Plenty of shops to browse and eat. Very very crowded as expected. If you plan to buy items here, I would recommend doing so outside of the main area where prices are almost double, particularly if stall owners know you are a tourist. Don’t forget to bargain!
Must visit in Shanghai, old and historical city. Different and amazing to experience old Shanghai.
Like it
many  people

data.formatted_address: China, Shang Hai Shi, Huang Pu Qu, 文庙路6F9Q+27P 邮政编码: 200010
data.name: 上海文庙

reviews.text: The only place in Shanghai I found myself alone. Of course the whole place is gorgeous as well and this is only amplified by this.

Highly recommended to go during weekdays or non public holidays to avoid the crowd. It's a lovely, neat and serene Confucian temple. It's hidden in residential areas so you need to look for it. 10 RMB for the entrant fee which I think it's absolutely worth it.

They hold a used book market here on Sunday mornings. That is an interesting sight and place to walk around. The Confucius temple itself that holds the market is also beautiful to walk around and take in.

10 rmb for entrance. There are a few chinese calligraphy pieces and a temple in the main area. Limited English explanation in the exhibit. There's also a tea house, which staff is really unfriendly. You'd need to buy their tea to explore that section, otherwise they'd chase you out.
Nice enough, but quite small and all the temples in China start to look the same

data.formatted_address: 1 You Yi Lu, Bao Shan Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200940
data.name: Wusong Ancient Fort

reviews.text: A beautiful park that was an amazing contrast to the bustle of Shanghai. Worth the trip out. They have redone most of the park so it looks different than some of the other pictures.
This is very peaceful and informative. The hero was killed there but his spirit will live forever!
10 minutes from Shanghai Cruise Terminal
I can’t feel the atmosphere of that year at all.

data.formatted_address: 10 Sha Jing Lu, Hong Kou Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200086
data.name: 1933 Old Millfun

reviews.text: If you're interesting in (british) brutalist architecture - explore this building during your stay in Shanghai! Very interesting design for an old slaughterhouse, with some shops and cafes inside. Does feel a little eerie and deserted but it adds to the experience!
Most unique architecture. Perfect place to take pictures. Lots of shoots were happening while we visited. There's a wonderful fashion shop selling runway items.
really cool architecture in an old area of shanghai. amazing place if you’re looking to see something different from the right rise building of pudong

This building was ahead of it's time when it was built, still impresses to this day. I would recommend going there during the week, because weekends are full of citizens from selfie nation and it's hard to get a nice photo without a lot of people on the background. That said, great place if you're interested in photography or architecture (or both). You will also find some cafes, small shops and office spaces. Recommended for people who are in Shanghai for a short time or if you live here and want to explore the city a little more.

Despite early visiting not many stores open yet, but the old concrete building with strange walkway connecting rooms and space looks interesting and is a good spot to take pictures.  It is going to be a hit and the area will soon be another happening n expensive in SH.  It s the young n creative people energy that give birth to this kind of place.

data.formatted_address: China, Shang Hai Shi, Hong Kou Qu, 长阳路62号 邮政编码: 200086
data.name: Shanghai Jewish Refugees Museum

reviews.text: Great museum representing the Jews who took refuge in Shanghai. Shows the level of respect and love the Chinese people have for the Jewish people. The synagogue is currently closed for renovation, but you can walk around the neighborhood and get a feel of the history. Make sure to visit the park across the street!

Originally built by the Russian Ashkenazi Jewish community in 1928, this synagogue lies in the heart of the 1940s Jewish ghetto. In 2007 it was restored using original blueprints discovered in archives. Today the building houses both the synagogue and the Shanghai Jewish Refugees Museum, with exhibitions on the lives of the approximately 23,000 Central European refugees who fled to Shanghai to escape the Nazis.

Unfortunately, I went there on Monday and on Monday this Museum remains closed and I just have to feel the place from outside. The museum is a touching testament to an era, a place, and a community of peoples helping each other, and I recommend that anyone, everyone, even without a connection, visit. It is very profound. Next time this will be the first place to visit...

Last day in Shanghai and decided to pay a visit to the museum since is 5 mins walking distance from my hotel. Was early as they opened at 9am. You can buy your tickets via wechat or alipay but because I'm a foreigner without local number, just go to the counter to buy the tickets with your passport. Walked up the stairs to the history of why and how Jewish flee to Shanghai and also some other countries to seek refugee. Their sufferings were unimaginable but the Chinese gave them the warmth and shelter greatly needed during these trying times. Worth a short visit. Took me about 30-45 mins to finish the exhibition.

Everywhere I go, I also check for jewish history. I knew that Jews were able to escape to China, but not all details. Not the stories, not how Chinese helped refugees while being under captivity themselves.....
worth a visit. This museum is small and gives a brief introduction about Jewish refugees during the world war 2. video room. photos.

data.formatted_address: China, Shang Hai Shi, Jia Ding Qu, 沪宜公路218号 邮政编码: 201802
data.name: Guyi Garden

reviews.text:
Unbelievably beautiful garden with amazing buildings.
I spent one whole day in this garden and I can say it was not even enough to see the whole area completely.
The first thing I recommend is to carry enough food and water with you because you will spend a whole day and you have to walk for hours. so you will need to refill your energy.
I hardly can describe its beauty and the peace you feel there.
I took hundreds of pictures.
And I saw young girls with traditional costumes taking pictures there.
Trees flower buildings the sound of the wind birds bridges river everything was just wow.
I really say it was a true heaven on the earth!
If one day I go to Shanghai again for 100% I will visit this garden again.
The interesting thing is that I accidentally found this place.
You do not need to buy a ticket in advance and you do not need to wait to enter the garden.
Just go and enjoy this heavenly place!

The GuYi garden is an excellent place to visit and experience the beauty and style of the Classical Chinese gardens.  There are several of those in Shanghai and Suzhou, but the benefit of GuYi is that it is off the beaten track and a lot more peaceful - thus more enjoyable
This garden was surprisingly huge. I enjoyed being able to get soup dumplings right next door. It was pretty and well kept, fairly busy.
Lovely park next to xiaolongbao street near the Nanxiang Metro stop (10 minute walk). 12rmb admission fee is totally worth it. Spent about 1.5 hours wandering around.

Gorgeous gardens which I stumbled across by accident, as I took a wrong turn to get to the old street. Lovely ponds, pavilions, and old bridges.

I went on a Saturday morning, and it was absolutely full of old Chinese folk playing games, dancing, and chatting. Quite an atmosphere!

Worth going here before the old street, and then have some of the area's most famous dish, Xiao Long Bao, on nearby GuYi street, which is full of restaurants that will be cheaper than most in the city.

data.formatted_address: 269 Da Jing Lu, Huang Pu Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200010
data.name: Dajing Ge Pavilion

reviews.text:
The Dàjìng Gé Pavillon is а museum and ancient temple of Shanghai, incorporating the last remaining portions of the walls of the Old City of Shanghai. Most of the walls were dismantled in 1912, and today only this portion remains.

The main pavilion was closed when I reached there, seems some renovation was going on...

Not hard to walk. Only one set of steps.
Can hire bikes to ride the wall, stop and buy an ice cream which is fun.
A few souvenir shops and about 6 places to b able to get the ground level.
The old city is a must-visit attraction in Shanghai. There is so much to see: gardens, markets, temples, food stalls, and plenty more. This is a great place to spend a day in Shanghai.
The wall is hidden behind the main road, just a step from the guocchi coffee shop.. is just a grey wall of 30m n 2 m high.. Nothing to see..
The city wall and markets around are ok, but not nearly as impressive as other Chinese cities. However, very nearby is Yu Garden which is beautiful and highly recommended to visit.

data.formatted_address: 1686 Nan Jing Xi Lu, 久光 Jing An Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200040
data.name: Jing'an Temple

reviews.text: Nice temple to visit when in Shanghai. There is a large tripod shrine in the court area where people burn incense sticks, and try to throw coins for good luck. The shrine is tall, so they try to throw the coins into its windows or onto it. A lot of fun for the kids, as well for adults!
Beautiful temple in the middle of dowtown Shanghai. Nice architecture and Buda statues. Worth visiting if you are 2/3 days in town.

Entrance fee 100 yuan per person. They accept instant online payment at the entrance gate. The candlesticks to be bought inside, online payment 10 yuan available again. It is a very nice 🛕 architecture. Many tourists, obviously, if you don't mind
Not a very good temple. There are many, many better temples in the world. This is just a light building to attract tourists. There is not even a big Buddha statue inside.

Jing'an Temple is a breathtaking and peaceful Buddhist temple that I had the pleasure of visiting during my trip to Shanghai last December. It's a stunning Buddhist temple that I highly recommend visiting.

Just be aware that the entrance fee is CNY 50, which I personally found to be a bit too much compared to other tourist attractions in Shanghai.

Apart from that, it's definitely worth a visit for its beauty and cultural sights.

data.formatted_address: China, Shang Hai Shi, Min Hang Qu, 青年路步行街5933+JGJ 邮政编码: 201101
data.name: Qibao Ancient Town

reviews.text:
For seniors and first-time visitors to China, it may be a place to visit in Shanghai. You can stroll around the neighborhood and enjoy a lot of street food. However, the buildings here are actually rebuilt after the original ancient buildings were demolished, so if you want to explore real historical cultural monuments, this may not be your first choice.
PS Avoid coming on public holidays

One of the ancient towns in Shanghai. Used to visit when I was living in Shanghai. Nice alleys filled with all kinds of knick knacks and interesting food from Stinky tofu to Balut type eggs.

Today we ate a green glutinous rice cake only available in spring, filled with black sesame, red bean paste or pork floss with salted egg yolk. Delicious.

Also ordered a UNESCO World Heritage food called Guan Dan. It’s basically egg yolk filled with a minced meat paste and then boiled. Served with soup that has coriander and seaweed. Yummy!

Absolutely mesmerising! A different part of the world! Youve got to be there during the day and at night- its a splendid area when its all lit up in lights. You get to see the history of china merging with modernity. You see chinese dressed in cultural attire. Food isnt the best- mostly traditional chinese.

Just a short street, gets crowded easily. Only visit it if you do not hv the time for longer side trips whilst in Shanghai. Try the stinky tofu or local wrapped glutinous rice (changs). The changs come with various fillings - good as snacks or even for breakfast.
For bigger ancient Watertowns, try Suzhou area. The nearest would be Zhujiajiao n Zhouzhuang; try Jinxi for the authentic experience, less touristy.
Continence location which is near to airport, and if you don’t have enough time to experience the typical style of old Shanghai, this place it’s worth to go, only 30mins from the Hongqiao station.

data.formatted_address: China, Shang Hai Shi, Huang Pu Qu, People's Square, 人民大道100号 邮政编码: 200003
data.name: Shanghai Urban Planning Exhibition Center

reviews.text:
A very unique and informative museum in Shanghai. At first I went to Shanghai Museum but fully booked so cannot get the ticket. Then I tried to visit this museum and have a pleasant surprise.
A lot of students and some tour come here. It is a nice museum to visit.
They have some small gift shop with unique things.

This is a pleasant surprise for us. As a native growing up in SH, it never occurred to me to visit this place until coming back after 9 years. The exhibits are very well laid out, mostly having English translations (so my American friends can enjoy as well). It does a fantastic job showing Shanghai’s past, present and future through many models, pictures and interactive exhibits. We spent 2 hours here but felt we could have spent more. Upon finishing the tour, it made me proud of being born in this amazing city.

This is a must-visit if you are interested on learning the history and future of China and Shanghai. There are many exhibits to explore. Foreigners can enter for free by showing their passport. Don't miss out on this interesting place if you have time on Shanghai.

Definitely worth a visit to understand China’s and Shanghai’s roadmap for 2030 and 2050 as well as a good dose of Chinese propaganda. Lots of innovation planned without much scientific backing. Rent the audio guide and plan on two hours to be able to view each exhibit which spans several floors.

Interesting exhibition on the history and ideal future of urban planning in Shanghai. Tickets are free which you can pick up outside the entrance at the reception - you'll need to show your passport. Some of the exhibits are visually stunning, although a lot of the info is only available in Chinese, so you may get more out of the experience with the audio guide.

data.formatted_address: Jing'An, China, 200041
data.name: Shanghai Natural History Museum.

reviews.text: I had a blast here! The building and surrounding park are beautiful on its own,  but the collection of taxidermy inside was astonishing - if you are sensitive to taxidermy , beware though, because there are entire habitats represented with hundreds of them, most of very good quality.   The insect and shell displays were fantastic too. Do remember to bring your passport and alipay or similar payment method.

Foreigners can buy tickets at the counter. At the Metro station. Amazing Dinosaur, Animal and gemstone exhibits. It's definitely one of the best Natural History Museum in the world. There is a beautiful sculpture garden outside the museum and it's near Nanjing Commercial Street.

Nice museum about natural history of China and Earth. There is a large zoological collection, including dinosaurs bones and statues.  Also you can find a hall with minerals. This museum will be interesting for both children and adults. If you have Chinese telephone number,  i would like to recommend you to book tickets online in advance. If you are a foreigner, then you can buy tickets inside. Price is 30 RMB.

Easy to access, very close to the Metro. I went with my parents. There're some discount for adult who aged over 60th. Not much food & restaurant there but there is a mall close to Metro. Please avoid weekends and holiday.

Great place. You can learn a lot of history and culture from this great museum. There is 5 stories exhibiting different historical artifacts. There is also a 4D movie theatre and more shows at the different levels which needs booking in advance. A must visit place when visiting shanghai unless you don’t like museums

data.formatted_address: 357W+QCW, Songjiang District, Shanghai, China, 201620
data.name: 广富林遗址

reviews.text:
Super accessible by #9 subway and then the 15 bus. It’s a huge scenic area. Was here on a weekday following a holiday so it was understandably less busy than usual but we practically had the whole area to ourselves at times which was absolutely amazing!! Very very few tourists, didn’t see any foreigners at all tbh

We spent the whole day just walking around and still wasn’t able to cover everything. Entrance is completely free with some paid museums and exhibits which I personally wouldn’t waste the time and money on.

Picturesque scenery all around. Worth spending a whole day, even in winter, wandering around the gardens, temples, and Hui-style buildings that make up the park. Only the exhibition hall, the ancient pottery museum, the archaeological museum, and maybe some other venues require paid admission. An all-in ticket is around 80 yuan. The outside grounds, the temple complex, and everything else is free of charge. Much is newly built, but it's elegant nonetheless. Like all venues in China, there are many boutiques, tearooms, and restaurants around. The bookstore, which doubles down as a small museum on the 2nd floor, is very nice. It's a 10-minute bus ride from the metro station.

Not suitable for non-Chinese speakers.
There are interactive activities to learn more about history of Shanghai which seems like a fun thing if you speak Chinese.
An archaeological site that has been rebuilt to it's former glory. A great place with picturesque landscape to stroll around. Vegetarian food is available here at an affordable price.
Shanghai Guangfulin Archaeology Site, where you can see the 5000 years of underwater cultural history.

data.formatted_address: 201 Ren Min Da Dao, People's Square, Huang Pu Qu, China, 200003
data.name: Shanghai Museum

reviews.text: The Shanghai Museum is an absolute must-visit for anyone interested in Chinese art and culture. With its vast collection of artifacts spanning thousands of years, it's like taking a journey through China's rich history. From ancient ceramics to exquisite jade sculptures, every exhibit showcases the beauty and craftsmanship of Chinese art. Whether you're an art enthusiast or simply curious about China's cultural heritage, the Shanghai Museum offers a captivating experience that's not to be missed.

It has been around ten years since our last visit and we were keen to see the exhibitions.   Then, there was a wonderful exhibit showcasing the terracotta warriors.

It was an interesting sight to see the building, which is in the shape of an old imperial wine cup traditionally used by the Emperor.

Unfortunately, this time, three of the galleries were closed, and the exhibit on Leonardo da Vinci had just ended. Nevertheless, they still had similar galleries showcasing the clothing and jewellery of the minority groups in China, as well as calligraphy and Chinese paintings.  We liked the wooden furniture exhibition.

All in all, we spent on,y an hour here this time, due to the gallery closures.

Entry is free via a QR code, and you need your passport. You can register at the booth outside near the souvenir store, and entry is then further round the corner at the southwest entrance.  The nearest Metro exit is number 1.

Great museum. I gave only 4 stars, just because it is very hard to reserve entrance ticket for weekend. The ticket is free, but you need to reserve it via museum website. You will need Chinese telephone number for that. They open slots in week before, but all slots for Saturday and Sunday are immediately reserved. I visited this museum twice. My second visit was not so successful: only several halls were open, others were closed for renewing. Very often there is a special exposition on the ground floor, and it could be not free.

It's a decent place to spend an hour. Quite crowded though as tourists and students alike all come in mass. There were 4 floors but only 2 open exhibits on the 4th floor, 1 open on the 3rd floor, and 1 open on the 1st floor. And the amount of people made it difficult to see an entire exhibit.
A treasure box of history with a very nice garden outside with parking space.  Museum personnel outside were very patient and helpful to everybody.  Very clean toilets.  Very interesting Museum Shop.

data.formatted_address: China, Shang Hai Shi, Xu Hui Qu, 龙华路2853号 邮政编码: 200232
data.name: Longhua Pagoda

reviews.text: This place has been one of the most special locations that I have ever been. Really peaceful and beautiful temple. We were in the celebrations of the day of the deaths and it was magical.
Great place, really beautiful and nice bit quite crowded
It's nice in spring when lot of flower and green plants are all around. The Pagoda Is nice but small, locked within a fence, it is not possible to go up.

It looks a little different than its representative in "Empire of the Sun," but no less fun to admire. It has recently been renovated and looks fantastic. I recommend reading u upon the history of it and the surrounding area before attending, it makes the experience more meaningful in my opinion.
Tall high tower , was closed to enter but I've heard that if u will make a circle around it praying u will be more lucky 😁so if u need some luck go ahead to check it out

data.formatted_address: 205 Shang Nan Lu, 周家渡 Pu Dong Xin Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200126
data.name: China Pavilion

reviews.text: Impressive architecture with interesting though limited art collection. Worth visiting even if your Shanghai visit is short. Easily accessible by Shanghai Metro.

“Massive Architecture”

Shanghai art museum also known as Shanghai expo pavilion, which is also one of the major tourist attractions. During the world expo of 2010 it was one of the most attractive pavilions among the lot.

After the completion of the expo it was converted into Shanghai art museum. The architecture of the building represents a king’s crown during the early ages of China.

There is no entry fee; however they give you a card at the entrance to pass through the electronic gate. The building is huge and stands out compared to other usual building constructions. I took an elevator to reach the top floor where they have displayed the history of China in different stages with elegant photography.

The whole building is in red, from inside & outside. Red is the national color of China and is also considered as the color of good luck. Each floor has a different kind of art display but I felt that the major display of photography was undoubtably of their greatest modern ruler Chairman Mao.

There are some places inside the museum where you need to buy a ticket to enter. I didn’t opt for such options and went around all the freely accessible areas before exiting the museum. Most of the buildings constructed for expo have been converted into something else, like shopping centers, restaurants, etc., however there are some which are still empty and has been closed for many years with no utilization at all.

Very interesting building, mixing contemporary with traditional Chinese references. The entrance is through the middle of the building by a huge escalator, which is quite unusual.
Unfortunately, the red beams do not extend into or have any presence once inside, making it look just as decoration.  The exhibitions were good (when I went, at least).

If you only have one day in Shanghai, go to China Pavillon to see the amazing "Along the River During the Qingming Festival". It captures the daily life of People and landscape of china a thousand years ago.
This is the place which is not crowded in China. However, I still recommended you to visit other more historical place than here.

data.formatted_address: 231 Nan Jing Xi Lu, People's Square, Huang Pu Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200003
data.name: People's Park

reviews.text:
This is a nice and large in the city center that provide visitors a place of serenity and tranquility from the busy and noisy traffic. There are lots of nice flowers and large greenery throughout the park where one can temporarily indulge in our mother's nature and enjoy peacefulness. It's a very nicely decorated park with colourful flowers and plants. There's also eatery, cafe and a flower shop there.

However, during our visit, the weather was super sunny and warm and so there wasn't many visitors and even if there were, most were taking cover under the shade of tress or in the cafes. As the park is located near our hotel, we did pass by it everyday several times and enjoyed our walk there especially in the early morning. It's quiet and air was fresh.

Shanghai's People's Park offers a lovely green space for relaxation. Take a walk under the trees, enjoy the pond, or have a picnic. On weekends, a section becomes a marriage market. It's interesting to see families showcasing profiles of their single children in hopes of finding a match. This cultural tradition offers a glimpse into how some families approach finding partners for their children. Whether you're seeking peace or cultural immersion, the People's Park is worth a visit.
A huge beautiful and clean public park. Can just buy a cup of coffee, and chill and people watching here for a few hours.
Beautiful park, except you enjoy sitting at the park enjoying the nature, nothing much in here.

The People's Park is also known as the Renmin Park, with a total area of 98,200 square meters (24.3 acres). It runs from Middle Xizang Road in the east to North Huangpi Road in the west, and extends from West Nanjing Road in the north to People's Square in the south. The park has eight gates; the main gate is located at no. 231 on the West Nanjing Road.

The park can be divided into three areas: the east area, the middle area and the west area. The major attraction in the east area is the Memorial to the May Thirtieth Movement. The Antarctic Stone, the Shanghai Museum of Contemporary Art, a teahouse, an outdoor theater, and a dance hall can be found in the vast middle area. Additionally, tourists can have a rest, play chess, or have a picnic on the stone tables and stone stools in the jungle of the middle area. Compared with the east and middle areas, the west part has a lot of landscape architecture, including pavilions, corridors, artificial hills, pools and pergolas.

data.formatted_address: 50 Mo Gan Shan Lu, Pu Tuo Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200071
data.name: 50 Moganshan Road

reviews.text:
We first visited this over 15 years ago, when it opened.  Then, it was just a budding place for artists, with small studios dotted about.

Today, it had grown into several buildings, with large galleries and experimental spaces.  It was good to see that artists are still around, though these seem to now be of younger age, and more into experimental art.

There is even a lifestyle store, selling quite unique and quaint 'period' furniture, and even offering coffee on the terrace.  There are also a number of small cafes, as well as a couple of restaurants.

Don’t visit this place during public holidays, most stores & galleries are closed. A small space for arts and creatives and there were a few cafes in this area. 10 minutes walk to the metro station, Jiang Ning Road (Line 1).

“Art enclave of shanghai”

M50 is one of the famous contemporary art zones of Shanghai. The place was actually a mill producing clothes, which was later converted into a place to display art.

Talking about the place, it has more than 100 art cafes with free entrance; the walls are all painted with different designs, art forms and graphics. The main aim of the artists is to display their art and to sell as much as possible.

Apart from paintings you can also find photo studios, fashion designers, etc. I could see lot of foreigners here more than the locals as this place is quite famous among the foreigners. If you are an art lover like me then this place is not to be missed.

M50 (莫干山路50号) is an industrial look/warehouse turned into art district kind of  place. It's free to the public and if you're a creative person/art enthusiast or even if you just want to check a cool open space with lots of galleries, studios, cafes and anything art related. Architects and photographers will have a good time visiting this place. There are countless alleys to discover, maybe one visit won't be enough, so come with time to walk around and seat down for a coffee and talk with your friends.
A fantastic space and make sure you look at the 1000 Trees shopping centre next door. Love the art community in M50. Quite a lot closed on Mondays, but still fun. For art lovers.

data.formatted_address: 279 Yu Yuan Lao Jie, 四牌楼 Huang Pu Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200000
data.name: Yu Garden

reviews.text:
Beautiful garden, but kind of a steep ticket price for a park/garden this size. Well worth seeing, still. Extremely photogenic. I wish we’d come earlier in the day, as it closes quite early and we’d have loved to stay longer (and get our money’s worth).

Most of the temples and parks we’ve seen in China were vast and have a sense of size and scope. This one is very quiet and intimate (despite the crowds) and lovely in a different way. It has a feel I associate more with Japanese gardens.

Yu Garden Shanghai is a touristy place and it can be very crowded even during the weekdays. The place was surrounded by Chinese architecture buildings and there were many souvenir shops & restaurants. A nice place to explore and recommended to try the ‘Xiao Long bao’.

An admission fee is required to visit the Chinese garden. The garden compound was relatively small and therefore it was crowded. The garden was well organized but nothing particularly impressive about it.

Go at night! It is much more beautiful when the buildings are lit up to accent the red and gold! Quite a big area with many photo opportunities and local market stalls. Geared towards tourists, but still amazing nonetheless. (The prices around the area will also be tourist prices however - just so you know)

This is a fairly large tourist park located in Shanghai.  This garden is filled with flowers and plants that are tens or even hundreds of years old.  Entering this park is like entering ancient China, I really like that.  In the park there is also a temple for worship.  I could barely find my way out of this park due to the lack of signs.  But in my opinion, this park is quite good and interesting to visit.

A truly picturesque place. The garden is beautiful and the architecture is incredibly detailed. Every step in here feels like walking in ancient China! Had a great time here but recommend going earlier for less people as it gets more crowded near the afternoon.

data.formatted_address: 201 Hong Mei Lu, Min Hang Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200237
data.name: Jinjiang Action Park

reviews.text: I visited some food stalls (outside the amusement park) that mimic Taiwan night market. Not too shabby.

This is a park mainly for the local residents and their kids. If you want to experience the local entertainment life, here is a good spot for the weekend.
Get there by the metro line 1. This is the most convenient way. For more information about  Shanghai,  twitter me@ jerryshanghai or email: accotek@163.com
Park has been renovated a few years ago, overall is ok.

Useless. Most rides are out not working.  The few rides that are working - is operated every 30 to 60minutes to save electricity. For 130rmb p.p you also have to pay extra for the ferris wheel. Not recommended.

I would not go there again..its low quality and most of the attractions w ere out  of function when we were there. The surrounding has no trees, everything in direct sun. ....and much of the equipment its quite to old to enjoy. we were really disappointed.

data.formatted_address: 78 Xin Zhen Lu, Min Hang Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 201101
data.name: Dino Beach Water Park

reviews.text: People chill in a water park in SW China's Chongqing after an orange level high temperature warning issued on Sunday.

As a water park, the business planning is pretty good. There's all kinds of sexy everywhere, and beach babe events are held regularly. The subtext is that even those who are sexier and more beautiful than you have taken off their clothes, so what else do you have to be ashamed of? In addition, various exciting projects require you to let go of your arms, so everyone naturally liberates their nature.
It is very important to make the necessary preparations before going. If you kindly think that so many people go, it will not be too outrageous. Let me tell you, they are getting rich based on your idea. Last time we went, we wasted a ticket to buy swimsuits and the like.

The lazy river and artificial beach are a lot of fun.
I always go there when I go to Shanghai in the summer.
Expensive cost for a water park. Additional amounts are required for services provided within the park

data.formatted_address: China, Shang Hai Shi, Pu Dong Xin Qu, 川沙新镇, 黄赵路No. 310 邮政编码: 201205
data.name: Shanghai Disneyland Resort

reviews.text: It was a wonderful time, we didn’t wait long in any line, it was our first stress free Disney vacation.

Disneyland is just amazing, so much fun highly recommend but there are a few things to be aware off. Everything is so expensive almost think of an expensive price for an ice cream then double it and that's your price. There is lots of queuing even weekday and with prebooked tickets. Areas such as the dinner area was just crazy busy. Be prepared to queue.

Growing up watching Disney’s cartoons and wondering how the castle of Sleeping Beauty would look like in reality, I was almost as excited as my wife and daughter were. We went in Mid July, on a hot sunny day. It was a weekday and we thought there’d be fewer people but we were wrong. It was fully crowded. We arrived early morning and tried a lot of rides. We managed to find some fast passes (but they are not easy to get and they are limited in quantity). We were able to do Tron, Pirates of the Caribbean Battle for the Sunken Treasure, Roaring Rapids and Jet Packs and we missed Soaring Over the Horizon (all these are worth taking). The place is amazing and very well designed, staff spoke English and was very, very helpful and considerate. They don’t allow to bring food but there are plenty of options inside. My recommendation would be to buy a two-day ticket and book a hotel in Disney town. And don't forget to see the firework at night.

The place was fun and theres a lot of attraction, its a good place to bring kids and family. Sadly the waiting time is too long , you can wait for more than 2 hours for an attraction but thats kinda normal for amusement parks so its alright. The toilet is pretty clean even though i saw a unflushed toilet once but its counted as clean since usually the toilet was worse than that.

I love this disney resort! staff are extremely helpful, everything is well priced (the cheapest disney you will ever experience) and overall a really pleasant experience. try and visit mid week for lowest crowds - we went on a Wednesday and managed 4 fast passes (still got new ones even at 4pm) and lots and lots of rides. definitely stay for the fireworks show at the end! i would visit over and over.

data.formatted_address: 888 Lin Hu Lu, Song Jiang Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 201602
data.name: 上海欢乐谷

reviews.text: Best rollercoaster ride I've been to, and I'm an adrenaline junkie, ofc like any amusement park there's a long wait time and rides closes around 8pm to 9pm, so getting the afternoon tix may not be so ideal if you wish to ride more things. Night scenery is good though. There's a water show at the end of the day, quite pretty too. There is a water park inside too (cost extra) but looks pretty fun bring your swimming trunks

Feels like the universal studios alternative. Rides are thrilling. Long queues at every rides. It will be good to have a VIP express fee for all rides instead of per ride basis.
The cleanliness of the toilets are acceptable but please fix the locks so that the doors can lock.
Overall worth visiting
A beautiful place for the whole family! Enjoy your day at Happy Valley. Alot of rollercoasters and eating opportunities. Cost 230 rmb for a day-ticket. Free shuttle bus from and to subway

The amusement park itself is quite nice and clean. A compact one day tour package may help the tourist go through all the sizzles and dazzles of the park. The downside is that just metres away from its boundaries there are a lot of rubbish and construction debris.

Okay so here is the deal: You have to visit this place when it opens up. You can't come during the day just at any random hour because all rides are X hours long waits. So - come at opening, be first, and choose the fireball (wood coaster fireball) ride because that's the 3 hours wait or so. Others are not such extreme and you'll wait max 30min-1h on each which is not that bad and you might just get on all the major rides there in one visit. Good luck! Oh, and the whole place is just pretty standard. Nothing majorly impressive about it.

data.name: Shanghai Film Park Tickets

reviews.text: Shanghai Film Park offers a glimpse into Chinese cinema with film sets, shows, activities & a museum. Explore movie scenes, watch live performances, learn filmmaking history & more. Great for movie buffs & culture enthusiasts!  Allow extra time for crowds, especially on weekends.

I enjoyed walking around for 2.5 hours (including a short break).
It isn't a theme park, it isn't a museum.
It is a little run down but they are making new buildings, I may go back in a year or more.
A nice place to hangout a day in Shanghai. However, I really wish that more doors opened with something interesting in it instead of trash. The entry costs 80 Yuan which is not so bad.

There are many old cars and backdrops of Shanghai as well as old ad boards scattered around the park. There are also extras and actors taking part in scenes during our visit. There are even old military vehicles in hangars and old movie posters and even an old metal ship.  It was the best part of the park, watching the crew work and photographers snapping photos. The place mimics old Shanghai streets with its trams, building facades and old brick streets. It is a taxi ride from the nearest metro station so it isn't very accessible from public transport.
If you love all chinese drama, film, movie, you gonna love this place! Must visit if you travel to Shanghai. 😊

reviews.text: I support zoos and aquariums that rescue animals that cannot live in their habitat. But KIDNAPPING and FORCING them into a tank is outrageous and I will never support a zoo or aquarium that kidnap healthy/non injured animals from their habitat!! We don't live in the 60s anymore, China! This is a horrible facility that should not be supported!
The Orca show was very good, they were very cute and the dolphin too, i played the lava drifting but not that scary, I love it!

This is by far my worst amusement park experience even if you exclude the likely animal abuse of orcas and dolphins. I went during dragon boat festival so it was insanely crowded. The cable cars cost money to wait for an hour. The Rollercoaster was closed. The ultraman restaurant was forcing people to buy food to use their patio. The firework display at 7 25 was nice, but then they block off most of the park for a parade that makes it impossible to leave. Don't come here

This theme park is supposed to be a cute park, but unfortunately the animals are not held properly. The space is way too small for the number of animals... should definitely be adjusted !!!
Also, the Chinese visitors drive one crazy, they cannot queue properly (or at all) and are often rude. This also made the visit worse
Can’t believe Orca show is still on in this day and age!!! Extremely disgusted. Worst park ever

reviews.text: It's still open, I was so confused, as I was not able to connect on phone. Two good rides and one 4d cinema. Build stations are good. Tickets not available on klook. Small cafe inside.

I went to China taking an 18 hrs flight spending 1100 dollars just for this Legoland Discovery Center and only for it. I was highly disappointed when I got there. None of the rides were working at the timeframe I was there as while none of the features and activities were accessible for my age and size. I felt the options and opportunities of the Shanghai, China Legoland Discovery Center were greatly reduced because of my experience while I was there and the time frame I was there for. I do not recommend The Legoland Discovery Center Shanghai China for anyone outside of the country but if you live nearby consider checking it out.
Pretty good for the kids to spend few hours. There's a cafe inside whilst the kids do their Lego thing.
Very crowded and very expensive for the amount that was charged for something not as great as one would expect lego centre
This Legoland is great! The inside playground is one of the best we've seen in the USA or China. The other attractions are similar to an American Legoland we have seen.

I never thought of buying chrysanthemums. However, if you are reading this... and if you are traveling to Shanghai, please... buy chrysanthemums and place them in front of the bust of Dr. Yun Bong-gil. I will definitely do the same next time.
It's near the Linear station.
Brilliant

A beautiful peaceful place in a busy city!
Beautiful park in Pudong, very quiet and peaceful when I was there!
Very nice park in the middle of Pudong. I am visiting end of March and the blossoms are everywhere.

An enormous, well-designed park in the heart of Pudong. There is always something happening here, and it is too big to plan to see it all in one day and enjoy it. The Metro runs right through it with a convenient entrance/exit. In recent years many of the skateboarders have been replaced with baby strollers  and wheelchairs, it's like there's no in between. Mostly the latter.

data.formatted_address: 1 Shi Ji Da Dao, Lujiazui, Pu Dong Xin Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200120
data.name: Oriental Pearl TV Tower

reviews.text: I just had the most epic view of Shanghai from the Oriental Pearl Tower! Seriously, the observation deck gives you this insane panoramic view of the entire city. You can see everything from towering skyscrapers to bustling streets. It's like being in a movie! If you want to capture the essence of Shanghai's awesomeness, you've got to visit this place.

The scenery was very nice when I came there at the end of last year (2023). The view was very nice blended with the sunset in the background. Even though visiting can cause a long walk around to and from different malls too, it is a sight not to miss. I also recommend getting down and going closer than the ring too ;)

The Oriental Pearl TV Tower, located in Shanghai, China, stands as an iconic symbol of modern architecture and technological prowess. Soaring 468 meters into the sky, this remarkable structure captivates visitors with its unique design, featuring spheres and columns that resemble pearls on a string.

Ascending the tower provides breathtaking panoramic views of the cityscape, including the impressive skyline along the Huangpu River. The observation decks offer a mesmerizing spectacle, especially during the evening when the city lights illuminate the surroundings. The tower's design seamlessly blends traditional Chinese elements with a futuristic touch, creating an aesthetic marvel that appeals to both locals and tourists.

Beyond its visual appeal, the Oriental Pearl TV Tower houses an exhibition showcasing the evolution of technology and broadcasting in China. Interactive displays and multimedia presentations offer an educational experience, providing insight into the country's rapid development.

While some critics argue that the tower's appearance might be too futuristic for its historic surroundings, the majority appreciate it as a symbol of China's progress and embrace its role in shaping Shanghai's modern identity. In conclusion, the Oriental Pearl TV Tower is not just a television broadcasting hub; it's a cultural landmark that bridges the past and present in a visually stunning way.

Very crowded with many people. It took 10-15 mins to get on the elevator, but the view was magnificent. Personally, I loved the view when looking down from the glass floor, which was really cool. Travelling with friends here is a good way to pass time and have a lot of fun!

Excellent tourist destination in Shanghai, view from the top of the tower, the glass floor appears magnificent, particularly when the sky turns dark. I was there in summer early April. The museum in the tower depicts history and culture, which is great. If you buy your tickets ahead of time, you will save money and have a shorter wait time.

data.formatted_address: 210弄 Tai Kang Lu, Huang Pu Qu, China, 200023
data.name: Tianzifang

reviews.text:
Tianzifang is one of the popular tourist destinations in Shanghai for shopping and experiencing local culture and lifestyle. It is located in the old French concession area. The area has mainly retained the "authentic and original" feeling because it has not been reconstructed or rebuilt. Instead visitors will get to see buildings, shophouses, alleys and streets of the old French concession area with Chinese "culture".

It has now become famous as a "rabbit warren" of arts and crafts shops, with restaurants, bars, cafes, souvenir and boutique shops etc. It has become touristy but still a good place to have a feel of the local touch.

I enjoy walking around in the small lanes around the old ancient buildings with beautiful decorations as it is quite difficult to find them these days due to the city redevelopment!

This is an easy place to get to via the Metro.
Spent a few hours exploring this tourist destination. There are some interesting shops and sights but there are certainly some repeat shops and themes.
It is worth visiting if you are in the area and have not been before, but you will not have missed anything if you never visit.
Quite a few food stalls selling standard street food. All look good and the few stalls I tried tasted ok too. Had the tofu, fried squid, and a coffee.
Went to the shopping center above the metro for dinner.

Tianzifang is a lively and fascinating area in Shanghai, known for its narrow alleyways filled with unique shops, art studios, and cafes. The atmosphere is vibrant and full of energy, making it a great place to explore.

One of the main attractions of Tianzifang is the variety of small boutiques offering handmade crafts, jewelry, and other interesting items. It’s a perfect spot for finding unique gifts and souvenirs.

The area also has a strong artistic vibe, with many galleries and studios showcasing local art. It’s a great place to experience the creative side of Shanghai.

Overall, Tianzifang is a must-visit for anyone in Shanghai looking to experience a different side of the city. It’s full of charm and always has something new to discover.
Not sure what culture or remnants of french concession you can find here, I just see refurbished old buildings with tourist focused shops. Definitely a tourist trap.
One of my favorite places to visit in Shanghai, it is just so picturesque! Nice little shops, well decorated alleys, great snacks around and so perfect for taking pictures!

data.formatted_address: 98 Feng He Lu, Lujiazui, Pu Dong Xin Qu, China, 200120
data.name: Waitan Sightseeing Tunnel

reviews.text: It was a fun ride! It was relatively cheap (if you consider it an attraction), fast and easy to use.
This is so cheesy, quirky, and lame, that it is hard not to love it for that.
for ¥50 per person, it's a quick way to get across the Bund when you don't want to walk back to the subway, or stuck in traffic on a taxi.
A must see location for tourists. You can learn a lot about the city and its history

This place was amazing to experience. Price was good not too expensive though not too cheap. Very friendly staff. Places to eat. Lots of photos taken and the ride under the huangpo river in little "carts" to get from one side to the other along with music, pictures, light displays ect. Was really amazing. Would reccomend this.

reviews.text: Small and charming water city, definitely must visit! Very comfortable to reach - about 80 minutes by subway from the city center and you will discover real Venice of Shanghai. I would suggest just get lost in this town - try local food, teas, take slow walks and enjoy all beauty of Zhujiajiao.

The ancient town is bustling with tourists and offers local food and Chinese costume shops along the walkway. However, the prices inside are slightly higher than elsewhere, but it seems like customers are willing to pay. The atmosphere is pleasant and perfect for photos. It's a good option if you have a free day to explore.
Very less boat ride experience. Overcharged for town experience with old ancient garden with english speaking guide. We 4 were charged 32,000 Rs in total.

Step back in time as you wander through the picturesque streets of Shanghai Zhujiajiao Ancient Town. Marvel at the well-preserved architecture and tranquil waterways that give this historic town its charm. It’s the perfect escape from the hustle and bustle of the city.
Very nice scenery. So refreshing with the nature. Recommend to visit around sunset the view on the old bridge really beautiful. Not too crowded on weekdays.

data.name: Nanjing Road Pedestrian Street

reviews.text: Nanjing pedestrian street in the evening is an absolute delight! As one of Nanjing's most popular shopping destinations, this bustling street offers a dynamic blend of culture, commerce, and charm. Stretching for kilometers from the Bund to the People's Park, its length ensures there's always something new to discover along its vibrant path. The illuminated atmosphere, adorned with colorful lights and animated by the lively crowd, creates an unforgettable experience. With a diverse range of shops offering everything from fashion to souvenirs, Nanjing pedestrian street is the perfect place for a leisurely stroll and some retail therapy. Whether you're a visitor or a local, I highly recommend experiencing the magic of Nanjing pedestrian street for an enjoyable evening out in the city!

Definitely a Top-5 things to do while in Shanghai, especially if it’s your first time to the big city.  It is a long, semi-closed off walking street that starts from the Bund (that glamorous roll of old Colonial Shanghai buildings) and has hotels, shopping malls, restaurants, large brand stores, and shops lining up on both sides of the walking street.  One can easily spend a whole day (and more) sight-seeing, taking in the atmosphere, watching people, shopping and tasting all sort of local and international foods and drinks on offer.  It is a good way to experience both the old and new Shanghai all combined into one. Just wear comfortable walking shoes and suitable coats or jackets depending on the season.

This is a pedestrian street (around f 2 km) from  Shinsegae Department Store in front of People's Square Station to Bund.

The best Metro station is East Nanjing Road to the Bund where there are many shops, restaurants and street foods.
This is the best place to enjoy the Shanghai, Day and Night.

This very busy and long street is lined with countless shopping malls, street foods, and street performances, offering a unique experience. It's a must-visit, especially at night to make the experience even more exciting. Don't miss out on this if you are coming to Shanghai!

One of the top walking streets in Shanghai that you should not miss. This is known as a  shopping promenade and there are many shop on both sides of the street. Great place during the day as well as in the night to witness the beauty of Shanghai. Bit crowded during the evenings.

Beautiful and very clean. It also has aovley view of the shanghai tower.
What a wonderful view at night during winter time!

One of the must visit place when you are in Shanghai.very beautiful and scenic with Different types of flowers,plants and lawn. You can access the place by taking a double decker bus city tour of apx 50 yuan. Best place for spending time and photography.
Beautiful and big park in Shanghai Downtown area, near the Bund and Yu Garden. It has nice spots to photograph the skyscrapers and a few hidden 5-star cafés worth visiting.

what a view of the unique buildings and constructions in the evening lightings , worth visiting
Good View!
worth visiting

It's a very attractive place
The beautiful buildings alone are worth seeing, but the night view decorated with lights is completely different from the night views we know in Japan! The dynamic and moving scenery allows you to keep drinking without getting bored.
However, there are a lot of people anyway😅

this is riverside view of tall buildings and River walk way where you can walk with beautiful sight seen of buildings.
in the night it even more attractive with lights.so many shops and shopping malls located near by.

In the basement of the Bund Financial Centre (North) is a food court calles Happily Ever After. There is a small restaurant called Yuan's Dumplings which is a excellent spot to rest and recover. The soup and dumpling combos are very good. Good soup dumplings of Veggie, Prawn, or Pork. The beef curry soup was very good as well and the servers are friendly helping out the foreigners. data.formatted_address: 501 Yin Cheng Zhong Lu, Lujiazui, Pu Dong Xin Qu, Shang Hai Shi, China, 200120
data.name: Shanghai Tower

reviews.text:
Awesome tower!

Had a wonderful experience taking 18 m/s high-speed elevator to the highest floor (fl 118) just under 1 minute. Unfortunately, it was super cloudy day so we could not clearly see the beautiful view from above.

They sell some souvenirs here and you can also get a free photo of you with no background. If you want it with background, you have to pay some.

Thank God I had chance to see the beauty of the tower at night.

Worth to visit!

The Shanghai Tower is truly a marvel of modern architecture. Its sleek design and towering presence redefine the city skyline. I was captivated by its intricate details and innovative construction. If you appreciate architectural brilliance, a visit to the Shanghai Tower is a must. Moreover, both the W Hotel and EDITION Hotel suites offered breathtaking views of this iconic tower, allowing me to marvel at its grandeur day and night.

I would say that the observation deck is a must do for anyone coming to Shanghai for the first time. A wonderful view of the city. Go towards sunset time so that you can get a view when it's bright and when it's dark and the lights come on. However, do be cautious of the weather... Avoid on days when the clouds hang low, the views will be obstructed.

Awesome view from top.. much visit places if you are going to Shanghai and do visit on the top floor it gives such a or some bird eye view of the whole city. Most enjoyable part gonna be the lift it goes so fast to the top .. make sure you have water bottle with you, water is really expensive up on the top

Amazing and beautiful building would recommend go for night or early evening. Love this building and this is the top of the Shanghai 😍🇨🇳😍 360 degree view from top. Shanghai is on another level with this building

data.formatted_address: 170 An Yuan Lu, Jing An Qu, China, 200061
data.name: Jade Buddha Temple

reviews.text: Loved this temple. You should not miss it if you visit Shanghai. Architecture is amazing. Buda’s statues are one better than the other. Strongly recommend visiting!

Lots of idols. Different kinds. Each person worshipping a different idol. There was the reclining buddha which was interesting. It was difficult to understand why people were prostrating to all the man made idols and praying to them. The architecture was absolutely fabulous. The engravings quite sophisticated.

I visited the Jade Buddha Temple in May of 2016 via public transport. It was relatively easy to get to, you just have to pay attention to the signage. The temple itself is beautiful and I was lucky to visit when the monks were in meditation so I sat on a walkway and just listened. It was a lovely experience. Things to note: The do offer a vegetarian buffet and there is a small shop.

Visited Oct 2015

The Jade Buddha Temple was founded in 1882 with two jade Buddha statues imported to Shanghai from Myanmar by sea. These were a sitting Buddha (1.95 meters tall, 3 tons), and a smaller reclining Buddha representing the Buddha's death. The temple now also contains a much larger reclining Buddha made of marble, donated from Singapore.

Would be great visit if there was not so much else to see - but enjoyable none the less.

Great place, filled with spirituality. Really recommended for a quiet break from the chaotic city
Some troubles with ticket payment at the cashier, easily solved with the nearby ATM.
